question: Question_07_(c)
statement:
An open metal tank has two ends which are isosceles triangles with
vertex at the bottom, two sides which are rectangular, and an open top.
The tank is 1 metre wide, 2 metres deep, 10 metres long and full of
water (\emph{density = 1000 kg/m\textsuperscript{3}}).

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
(c) Express the hydrostatic force on each of the rectangular sides as an
integral. (\emph{Do not evaluate the integral.})
\end{description}
sols:
\emph{Hydrostatic Force was not covered in the 2012 offering of this
course. Time might better be spent solving other problems given how soon
the exam is coming.}

Consider the rectangular side picture right.
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math101Apr20097c1.png} We will define the coordinate
along with width of the rectangle as z. Consider a thin rectangle at a
fixed z with length 10 (as pictured). The hydrostatic force on this
rectangle is,

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}dF=\rho{g}h(z)10\textrm{d}z.\end{align*}

Notice that the depth here is a function of z since each little
rectangle will correspond to a different depth in the tank. To determine
the depth as a function of z consider the side view of the rectangular
side where the width is actually the side of a triangle (pictured left)
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math101Apr20097c2.png}. We have only draw half of the
triangle to highlight that we can use right triangle trigonometry. We
know that the height of this triangle is 2 and the length is 1/2 (half
of the base of the full triangle). From the diagram, we define $\theta$
to be the angle between the vertical line and the hypotenuse and we have
that

\begin{align*}\theta=\arctan\left(\frac{1}{4}\right).\end{align*}

Recall that the variable z indicates the distance along the hypotenuse.
For a given z we can get the vertical length of the corresponding right
triangle, y, as

\begin{align*}y=2-h(z)=z\cos\theta=\frac{4}{\sqrt{17}}z.\end{align*}

Therefore we have that

\begin{align*}h(z)=2-\frac{4}{\sqrt{17}}z\end{align*}

which we can substitute into our hydrostatic force to get,

\begin{align*}dF=\rho{g}\left(2-\frac{4}{\sqrt{17}}z\right)10\textrm{d}z.\end{align*}

Now z starts at the bottom of the rectangle (which we will define as
z=0) and ends at the full length of the triangular side. We can use
Pythagorean theorem to get that the full length of that side is
$\sqrt{2^2+(1/2)^2} = \frac{\sqrt{17}}{2}$. Therefore we have that the
hydrostatic force is,

\begin{align*}F=\int_0^{\frac{\sqrt{17}}{2}}\rho{g}\left(2-\frac{4}{\sqrt{17}}z\right)10\textrm{d}z.\end{align*}

Since we are asked to set up the integral but not evaluate it, we are
now done.
hints:
The rectangular side may seem like a trivial calculation but recall that
the width of the rectangle is the same as one of the sides of the
triangle and so the length of this side will relate to the triangle in
some way.
